page.title: Higher education bubble in the United States

revision.text:
{{Education in the U.S.}} The '''higher education bubble''' in the United States is a claim that excessive investment in higher education could have negative repercussions in the broader economy. According to the claim{{snd}} generally associated with [[Fiscal conservatism|fiscal conservatives]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Archibald|first=Robert B.|last2=Feldman|first2=David (David H.)|title=State Higher Education Spending and the Tax Revolt|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/article/198686|journal=The Journal of Higher Education|volume=77|issue=4|pages=618–644|doi=10.1353/jhe.2006.0029|issn=1538-4640}}</ref>{{snd}} while college [[tuition payments]] are rising, the supply of college graduates in many fields of study is exceeding the demand for their skills, which aggravates [[graduate unemployment]] and [[Higher education in the United States#College major by underemployment rate|underemployment]], which in turn increases the burden of [[student loan]] [[Default (finance)|defaults]] on [[financial institution]]s and [[taxpayer]]s.<ref>{{cite web| last =Barshay| first =Jill| title =Reflections on the underemployment of college graduates| website =Hechniger Report| publisher =Teachers College at Columbia University| date =4 August 2014| url =http://educationbythenumbers.org/content/underemployment-college-grads_1589/| accessdate = 30 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Citation| last =Coates| first =Ken| last2 =Morrison| first2 =Bill| author2-link =| title =Dream Factories: Why Universities Won't Solve the Youth Jobs Crisis| place =Toronto| publisher =Dundurn Press| year =2016| pages =232| url =https://www.dundurn.com/books/Dream-Factories| isbn =978-1459733770 }}</ref> Also, some claim that employers have responded to the oversupply of graduates by raising the academic requirements of many occupations [[credentialism and educational inflation|higher than is really necessary to perform the work]].<ref>{{cite news | last =Pappano | first =Laura | title =The Master's as the New Bachelor's | newspaper =The New York Times | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =22 July 2011 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/24/education/edlife/edl-24masters-t.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 | access-date =10 September 2011 }}</ref> The claim has generally been used to justify cuts to public higher education spending, [[tax cut]]s, or a shift of government spending towards the [[criminal justice]] system and the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-budget-republicans-idUSKBN0MD1KU20150317|title=U.S. Republican budget cuts social spending, boosts military|date=2015-03-17|newspaper=Reuters|access-date=2016-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.debate.org/opinions/should-the-u-s-cut-spending-on-education-yes-or-the-military-no|title=Should the U.S. cut spending on education (yes) or the military (no)?|website=www.debate.org|access-date=2016-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/politics-government/article63347152.html|title=Gov. Sam Brownback cuts higher education as Kansas tax receipts fall $53 million short|website=kansascity|access-date=2016-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbpp.org/research/changing-priorities-state-criminal-justice-reforms-and-investments-in-education|title=Changing Priorities: State Criminal Justice Reforms and Investments in Education {{!}} Center on Budget and Policy Priorities|website=www.cbpp.org|access-date=2016-05-09}}</ref>
== Discussion == [[Benjamin Ginsberg (political scientist)|Benjamin Ginsberg]] explains the connection between the increased ability to pay tuition and the increase in services provided in his book ''The Fall of the Faculty.'' According to Ginsberg, "there have been new sorts of demands for administrative services that require more managers per student or faculty member than was true in the past."<ref>{{cite book|last=Ginsberg|first=Benjamin|title=The fall of the faculty : the rise of the all-administrative university and why it matters|year=2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=978-0199782444|page=28}}</ref> The [[Goldwater Institute]] echoes this sentiment with its findings that, "Between 1993 and 2007, the number of full-time administrators per 100 students at America's leading universities grew by 39 percent, while the number of employees engaged in teaching, research or service only grew by 18 percent."<ref>{{cite web|last=Jay|first=Greene|title=Administrative Bloat at American Universities: The Real Reason for High Costs in Higher Education|url=http://goldwaterinstitute.org/article/administrative-bloat-american-universities-real-reason-high-costs-higher-education|publisher=Goldwater Institute|accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref>
As discussed below, the "higher education bubble" is controversial and has been rejected by some economists. Indeed, many Americans still believe in the value of a college education, although they are unsure about its quality and affordability. Data shows that the wage premium{{snd}} the difference between what those with a four-year college degree earn and what those with only a high school education earn{{snd}} has increased dramatically since the 1970s, but so has the 'debt load' incurred by students due to the tuition inflation.<ref name = Simkovic>Michael Simkovic, [http://ssrn.com/abstract=1941070 Risk-Based Student Loans] (2012)</ref><ref name="Thomas Lemieux 2006">Thomas Lemieux, Postsecondary Education And Increasing Wage Inequality, 96 AM. ECON. REVIEW 195 (2006)</ref><ref name="chronicle.com">Sandy Baum and Michael McPherson, [http://chronicle.com/blogs/innovations/job-skill-trendsthe-college-wage-premium/27091 Job-Skill Trends and the College-Wage Premium], Chronicle of Higher Education, Sept. 21, 2010</ref> The data also suggests that, notwithstanding a slight increase in 2008–09, student [[Default (finance)|loan default]] rates have declined since the mid-1980s and 1990s.<ref name="phys.org">{{cite web|title=Student loan default rates jump|date=12 September 2011|first=Justin|last=Pope|website=Phys.org|publisher=Science X network|url=http://phys.org/news/2011-09-student-loan-default.html}}</ref><ref name="Kirkham">{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/12/for-profit-colleges-student-loan-_n_959058.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Chris | last=Kirkham | title=Led By For-Profit Colleges, Student Loan Defaults At Highest Level In A Decade | date=September 12, 2011}}</ref> Those with college degrees are much less likely than those without to be unemployed, even though they are more expensive to employ (they earn higher wages).<ref name="Education Pays">U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, [http://www.bls.gov/emp/ep_chart_001.htm Education Pays]</ref> The global management consulting firm [[McKinsey and Company]] projects a shortage of college-trained workers, and a surplus of workers without college degrees, which would cause the wage premium to increase, and cause differences in unemployment rates to become even more dramatic.<ref>McKinsey Global Institute, [http://www.mckinsey.com/Insights/MGI/Research/Labor_Markets/An_economy_that_works_for_US_job_creation An Economy that Works: Job Creation and America's Future], June 2011</ref> What is also interesting is that the cost of tuition over last 4 years from 2009–12 has been increasing steadily over the years while wages have remained stagnant. The inflation has been at really low levels in US in past 4 years and there are no explainable reasons why [http://studyn.us/2014/09/13/cost-masters-us-a-significant-rise-over-the-years%20 Cost of Masters / Graduation] is rising higher than inflation
In 1971, ''[[Time magazine|Time]]'' ran an article "Education: Graduates and Jobs: A Grave New World," which stated that the supply of post-graduate students was around twice larger than the expected future demand in upcoming decades.<ref name=north/> In 1987, [[U.S. Secretary of Education]] [[William Bennett]] first suggested that the availability of loans may in fact be fueling an increase in tuition prices and an education bubble.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Our Greedy Colleges|date=Feb 18, 1987|publisher=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/opinion/our-greedy-colleges.html|first=William J.|last=Bennett}}</ref> This "Bennett hypothesis" claims that readily available loans allow schools to increase tuition prices without regard to [[Price elasticity of demand|demand elasticity]]. [[College and university rankings|College rankings]] are partially driven by spending levels,<ref>{{Cite journal|title=How U.S. News Calculates the College Rankings|year=2010|publisher=[[US News and World Report]]|url=https://www.usnews.com/education/articles/2010/08/17/how-us-news-calculates-the-college-rankings}}</ref> and higher tuition prices are correlated with increased public perceptions of {{linktext|prestige}}.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Estimating the Payoff to Attending a More Selective College: An Application of Selection on Observables and Unobservables|year=1999|publisher=Dale, S. B. and Krueger, A. B., NBER|url=http://www.irs.princeton.edu/pubs/pdfs/409.pdf}}</ref> Over the past thirty years, demand has increased as institutions improved facilities and provided more resources to students.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=The Credits that Count: How Credit Growth and Financial Aid Affect College Tuition and Fees|year=2011|publisher=Ley, K. and Keppo, J., SSRN|ssrn=1766549|doi=10.2139/ssrn.1766549|last1=Ley|first1=Katharina|last2=Keppo|first2=Jussi|journal=}}</ref> Additionally, schools tend to enroll fewer students as they improve student offerings and increase prices. This suggests that it is in schools' best interest to increase tuition prices as much as possible, so long as financial aid ensures an ability to pay on the part of students and parents.
A variation on the higher education bubble theory suggests that there is no general bubble in higher education{{snd}} that is, on average, higher education really does boost income and employment by more than enough to make it a good investment{{snd}} but that degrees in some specific fields may be overvalued because they do little to boost income or improve job prospects, while degrees in other fields may in fact be ''undervalued'' because students do not appreciate the extent to which these degrees could benefit their employment prospects and future income. Proponents of this theory have noted that schools charge equal prices for tuition regardless of what students study, the interest rate on federal student loans is not adjusted according to risk, and there is evidence that undergraduate students in their first 3 years of college are not very good at predicting future wages by major.<ref name="Simkovic"/>
A 2011 article in ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', related concern that new college graduates hiring rates are up by 10 percent and that attaining a secondary level education eventually pays off. It is also suggested that high school graduates are three times more likely to live in poverty than students with higher education degrees. A recent study from the Labor Department suggests that attaining a bachelor's degree "represents a significant advantage in the job market".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/08/30/class-2011-hiring_n_942571.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Alexander | last=Eichler | title=Hiring Is Up For The Class Of 2011, But Previous Classes Still Struggle | date=August 30, 2011}}</ref> However, the article also claims that those who only have a high school education{{snd}} unemployment is slightly higher at a rate of 9.3 percent. The proponents of the article also claim that companies are most likely to hire an applicant straight from college rather than one who has been unemployed.
A 2010 article in ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'', suggest ten main benefits of obtaining a degree via higher education. Also suggesting that a college degree pays off financially and intangibly for the graduate, and overall for society. In November 2011, ''[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]'' ran an article claiming that the future is bright for college graduates and expected to improve.<ref>{{cite web|date=17 November 2011|title=Job Outlook for College Graduates Is Slowly Improving|first=Lacey|last=Johnson|website=The Chronicle of Higher Education|url=http://chronicle.com/article/Job-Outlook-for-College/129808/}}</ref> A rapid 10% increase is anticipated for new bachelor's hires. A survey conducted by ''[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]'' suggests that 40 percent of 3,300 employers plan to hire graduates from all fields of study. The survey suggested stability in the upcoming job market.
A 2009 article in ''[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]'', related concern from parents wondering whether it is worth the price to send their children to college.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://chronicle.com/article/Will-Higher-Education-Be-the/44400|title=Will Higher Education Be the Next Bubble to Burst?|author=Joseph Marr Cronin and Howard E. Horton|date=May 22, 2009|publisher=The Chronicle of Higher Education}}</ref> ''[[The Economist]]'' in turn hypothesized that the bubble bursting may make it harder for colleges to fill their classes, and that some building projects will come to a halt.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/lexington/2009/06/the_higher_education_bubble|title=The higher education bubble|publisher=The Economist|date=June 11, 2009}}</ref> The ''[[Boston Herald]]'' further suggested the possibility of [[Mergers and acquisitions|mergers]], closures and even bankruptcies of smaller colleges that have spent too much and taken on too much debt.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Higher-education bubble could burst next|author=Fitzgerald, Jay|date=May 31, 2009|url=http://news.bostonherald.com/business/general/view.bg?articleid=1175836|publisher=Boston Globe}}</ref> ''[[National Review]]'' writer Dan Lips has proposed that the bubble's bursting may bring down higher education prices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://article.nationalreview.com/427786/popping-the-higher-education-bubble/dan-lips|title=Popping the Higher-Education Bubble|date=15 March 2010|website=National Review|first=Dan|last=Lips|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100322194048/http://article.nationalreview.com/427786/popping-the-higher-education-bubble/dan-lips|archivedate=22 March 2010}}</ref>
[[Glenn Reynolds]] wrote in the ''[[Washington Examiner]]'' that those who have financed their educations with debt may be particularly hard-hit.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Further thoughts on the higher education bubble|author=Glenn Harlan Reynolds|publisher=Washington Examiner|date=August 8, 2010|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/opinion/columns/Sunday_Reflections/Glenn-Harlan-Reynolds-Further-thoughts-on-the-college-tuition-bubble-100216064.html}}</ref> Reynolds continued arguing his case in ''The Higher Education Bubble'' where he noted that higher education, as a "product grows more and more elaborate{{snd}} and more expensive{{snd}} but the expense is offset by cheap credit provided by sellers who are eager to encourage buyers to buy."<ref>{{cite book|last=Reynolds|first=Glenn H.|title=The higher education bubble|year=2012|publisher=Encounter Books|location=New York|isbn=1594036659|pages=1}}</ref>
Further speculation as to the higher education bubble was the focus of a series of articles in ''[[The Economist]]'' in 2011.<ref>[https://www.economist.com/blogs/schumpeter/2011/04/higher_education Higher Education, The Latest Bubble?] ''[[The Economist]]'', April 13, 2011</ref>
== Controversy == [[File:College Tuition State Funding.svg|thumb|400px|Study comparing college revenue per student by tuition and state funding in 2008 dollars<ref name=DeltaCost>"[http://www.deltacostproject.org/resources/pdf/Trends-in-College-Spending-98-08.pdf Trends in College Spending 1998–2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130808055659/http://www.deltacostproject.org/resources/pdf/Trends-in-College-Spending-98-08.pdf |date=2013-08-08 }}" (PDF) Delta Cost Project</ref>]]
The view that higher education is a bubble is controversial. Most [[economist]]s do not think the [[rate of return|returns]] to college education are falling{{snd}} in fact, the data suggests the rate of return is increasing.<ref name = Simkovic/><ref name="Thomas Lemieux 2006"/><ref name="chronicle.com"/><ref>{{cite book|title=The Race Between Education and Technology|author=Claudia Goldin, Lawrence F. Katz|publisher=The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press|year=2008}}</ref> Indeed, the returns to education are much higher than the returns to other forms of investment such as the stock market, bonds, real estate, and private equity. This suggests underinvestment in higher education{{snd}} the exact opposite of a bubble.<ref>{{Cite journal|ssrn = 2551567|title = The Knowledge Tax|last = Simkovic|first = Michael|date = 2015|journal = University of Chicago Law Review|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> Studies have typically found a causal relationship between growth and education, although the ''quality'' and type of education matters, and not just the number of years of schooling.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Benhabib|first1=Jess|last2=Spiegel|first2=Mark M.|title=The role of human capital in economic development evidence from aggregate cross-country data|journal=Journal of Monetary Economics|date=October 1994|volume=34|issue=2|pages=143–173|doi=10.1016/0304-3932(94)90047-7|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0304393294900477}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Pritchett|first1=Lant|title=Where has all the education gone?|url=https://www.hks.harvard.edu/fs/lpritch/Education%20-%20docs/ED%20-%20Econ%20Growth,%20impact/where%20has%20all%20the%20education%20gone.pdf|website=Harvard.edu|publisher=World Bank & Kennedy School of Government (2000)}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hanushek|first1=Eric A.|last2=Woessmann|first2=Ludger|title=How Much Do Educational Outcomes Matter in OECD Countries?|journal=IZA Discussion Paper No. 5401|date=December 2010|url=http://repec.iza.org/dp5401.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Holmes|first1=Craig|title=Has the Expansion of Higher Education Led to Greater Economic Growth?|journal=National Institute Economic Review|date=May 2013|volume=224|issue=1|pages=R29-R47|doi=10.1177/002795011322400103|url=http://ner.sagepub.com/content/224/1/R29.abstract}}</ref>
In a [[financial bubble]], assets like houses are sometimes purchased with a view to reselling at a higher price, and this can produce rapidly escalating prices as people speculate on future prices. An end to the spiral can provoke abrupt selling of the assets, resulting in an abrupt collapse in price{{snd}} the bursting of the bubble. Because the asset acquired through college attendance{{snd}} a higher education{{snd}} cannot be sold (only rented through wages), there is no similar mechanism that would cause an abrupt collapse in the value of existing degrees. For this reason this analogy could be misleading. However, one rebuttal to the claims that a bubble analogy is misleading is the observation that the 'bursting' of the bubble are the negative effects on students who incur student debt, for example, as the [[American Association of State Colleges and Universities]] reports that "Students are deeper in debt today than ever before ... The trend of heavy debt burdens threatens to limit access to higher education, particularly for low-income and first-generation students, who tend to carry the heaviest debt burden. Federal student aid policy has steadily put resources into student loan programs rather than need-based grants, a trend that straps future generations with high debt burdens. Even students who receive federal grant aid are finding it more difficult to pay for college."<ref>{{cite web | title=Student Debt Burden, Volume 3, Number 8, August 2006 | first=Nick|last=Hillman | publisher=[[American Association of State Colleges and Universities]] | year=2006 | url=http://www.aascu.org/media/pm/pdf/v3n8.pdf}}</ref> In this analogy, the increased inability of students to pay for their debt would represent the crash or bubble bursting, thus causing the tax payers to bail out the government for giving out bad loans -as the ratio of the aggregate debt compared to the aggregate earning potential grows to the tipping point, due to the finite amount of high paying positions, the limiting factor in this analogy.
However, the data actually show that, notwithstanding a slight increase in 2008–2009, student loan default rates have declined since the mid-1980s and 1990s.<ref name="phys.org"/><ref name="Kirkham"/> And even during the recession, those with college degrees are much less likely than those without to be unemployed, even though they earn higher wages.<ref name="Education Pays"/>
[[Ohio University]] economist [[Richard Vedder]] has written in the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' that:
{{quote|A key measure of the benefits of a degree is the college graduate's earning potential{{snd}} and on this score, their advantage over high-school graduates is deteriorating. Since 2006, the gap between what the [[median]] college graduate earned compared with the median high-school graduate has narrowed by $1,387 for men over 25 working full time, a 5% fall. Women in the same category have fared worse, losing 7% of their income advantage ($1,496). A college degree's declining value is even more pronounced for younger Americans. According to data collected by the [[College Board]], for those in the 25-34 age range the differential between college graduate and high school graduate earnings fell 11% for men, to $18,303 from $20,623. The decline for women was an extraordinary 19.7%, to $14,868 from $18,525. Meanwhile, the cost of college has increased 16.5% in 2012 dollars since 2006, according to the [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]]' higher education tuition-fee index.<ref>{{Citation|last=Vedder|first=Richard|last2=Denhart|first2=Christopher|title=How the College Bubble Will Pop|publisher=American Enterprise Institute|date=8 January 2014|url=http://www.aei.org/article/education/how-the-college-bubble-will-pop/|accessdate=12 July 2014 }}</ref>}}
Nader Habibi, who runs the website overeducation.org, writing in [[The New Republic]], cited this evidence:
{{quote|In a 2014 study, two economists affiliated with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York found that since 1990 at least 30 percent of all workers (aged 22 to 65) with college degrees have been consistently employed in jobs that do not require a college degree for the required tasks, even ten years after graduation. Not surprisingly, the percent of recent college graduates (aged 22 to 27) with such jobs has been much higher than the figure above and has ranged from 38 percent to 49 percent since 1990. ... The Obama administration recently created a valuable online database called College Scorecard to offer a more realistic picture of income prospects with a college degree. One of the indicators in this database shows that more than half of graduates at hundreds of colleges are earning less than the average income of someone holding a high school degree ($25,000 a year) ten years after enrollment. Ideally, this ratio should be zero. A large number of unemployed and underemployed graduates are also burdened with high student loan debts—more than $100 billion in 2013 alone—they have trouble paying back. We should not forget the billions that federal, state and local governments spend on higher education through subsidies and financial aid—$157.5 billion in 2014. The portion of this spending that supports the education of underemployed graduates could be used more effectively for job creation or training of students in vocational skills which are more in demand.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Habibi|first1=Nader|title=America Has an Overeducation Problem|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/124943/america-overeducation-problem|website=New Republic}}</ref>}}
=== Alternatives to bubble theory === A different proposal for the cause of rising tuition is the reduction of state and federal appropriations to colleges, making them rely more on student tuition. Thus, it is not a bubble, but a form of [[cost-shifting|shifting costs]] away from state and federal funding over to students.<ref name="24tuition">"[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/24/education/24tuition.html Public Universities Relying More on Tuition Than State Money]", ''[[The New York Times]]'' 2011/01/24</ref> This has mostly applied to public universities which in 2011 for the first time have taken in more in tuition than in state funding,<ref name="24tuition" /> and had the greatest increases in tuition.<ref name="DeltaCost" /> Implied from this shift away from public funding to tuition is [[privatization]], although ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that such claims are exaggerated.<ref name="24tuition" />
Another proposed cause of increased tuition is [[U.S. Congress]]' occasional raising of the 'loan limits' of student loans, in which the increased availability of students to take out deeper loans sends a message to colleges and universities that students can afford more, and then, in response, institutions of higher education raise tuition to match, leaving the student back where he began, but deeper in debt. Therefore, if the students are able to afford a much higher amount than the [[free market]] would otherwise support for students without the ability to take out a loan, then the tuition is 'bid up' to the new, higher, level that the student can now afford with loan subsidies.<ref>{{cite web | title=Federal Student Loans: Patterns in Tuition, Enrollment, and Federal Stafford Loan Borrowing Up to the 2007–08 Loan Limit Increase | publisher=gao.gov| year=2011 | url=http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-11-470R}}</ref> One rebuttal to that theory is the fact that even in years when loan limits have not risen, tuition has still continued to climb.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kargar|first1=Mahyar|last2=Mann|first2=William|title=Financial Aid and College Pricing: Estimates from the PLUS Program|url=https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2814842|website=SSRN|accessdate=6 January 2018|date=29 July 2016}}</ref> However, that may not disprove this proposed cause: It may instead mean that other factors besides 'loan limit' increases played a part in the increases in tuition.
A third theory claims that as a result of federal law that severely restricts the ability of students to discharge their federally guaranteed student loans in bankruptcy, lenders and colleges know that students are on the hook for any amount that they borrow, including late fees and interest (which can be capitalized and increase the principal loan amount), thus removing the incentive to only provide students loans that the students can be reasonably expected to repay.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Quinn|first1=Jane|title=Student Loans: Time to Reform the Law That Treats Debtors Like Crooks|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/student-loans-time-to-reform-the-law-that-treats-debtors-like-crooks/|accessdate=6 January 2018|agency=CBS News|date=24 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Weissman|first1=Jordan|title=How the Bush Administration Pointlessly Screwed Over Student Borrowers|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/moneybox/2015/04/16/student_loans_in_bankruptcy_how_the_bush_administration_pointlessly_screwed.html|website=Slate|accessdate=6 January 2018|date=16 April 2015}}</ref> As proof of this theory, it has been shown that returning bankruptcy protections (and other Standard Consumer Protections) to Student Loans would cause lenders to be more cautious, thereby causing a sharp decline in the availability of student loans, which, in turn, would decrease the influx of dollars to colleges and universities, who, in turn, would have to sharply decrease tuition to match the lower availability of funds.<ref name="Why College Prices Keep Rising">{{cite web | title=Why College Prices Keep Rising | publisher=Forbes.com| year=2012 | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/peterjreilly/2012/03/19/why-college-prices-keep-rising}}</ref> Under this theory, if student loans did not have the ability to file for bankruptcy, it would be more profitable for the lender if the student defaulted (due to the increases in the amount of the loan after fees and interest are capitalized), and thus there is no [[free market]] pressure-type motive for the lender or the college to help the student avoid default. This is especially true because the government, if it is the lender or guarantor of the loan, has the ability to garnish the borrower's wages, tax return, and Social Security Disability income without a court order.<ref>{{cite web| title=Student Loan Debt Surpasses Credit Card Debt-What to Do?| first=Howard| last=Dvorkin| publisher=foxbusiness.com| year=2010| url=http://www.foxbusiness.com/personal-finance/2010/09/20/student-loan-debt-surpasses-credit-card-debt| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110826033005/http://www.foxbusiness.com/personal-finance/2010/09/20/student-loan-debt-surpasses-credit-card-debt/| archivedate=2011-08-26| df=}}</ref> Some have called the Federal Government 'predatory' for making loans which will have such a high default rate, since the default rate for Student Loans is projected to reach 46.3% of all federal dollars disbursed to students at for-profit colleges in 2008 (Budget lifetime default rate, loan default rate only 18.6%, meaning that 18.6% of all loans contain 46.3% of all dollars loaned out).<ref>{{cite news | title=46 Percent Of Federal Loans Paid To For-Profit Institutions Will Go Into Default | publisher=huffingtonpost.com/AOL.com| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/23/46-percent-default-rate-o_n_800283.html | first=Danielle | last=Wienerbronner | date=December 23, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Subject: Default Rates for Cohort Years 2004–2008 | first=Katrina|last=Turner | publisher=ifap.ed.gov| year=2010 | url=http://ifap.ed.gov/eannouncements/122010CDRlifetimerate2010.html}}</ref>
Economic and social commentator [[Gary North (economist)|Gary North]] has remarked at [[LewRockwell.com]] that "To speak of college as a bubble is silly. A bubble does not pop until months or years after the funding ceases. There is no indication that the funding for college education will cease."<ref name=north>{{cite web|url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/north/north975.html|publisher=[[LewRockwell.com]]|accessdate=November 15, 2011|author=[[Gary North (economist)|Gary North]]|title=College: Why It Is Not a Bubble|date=May 2, 2011}}</ref>
[[Azar Nafisi]], [[Johns Hopkins University]] professor and bestselling author of ''[[Reading Lolita in Tehran]]'', has stated on the ''[[PBS NewsHour]]'' that a purely economic analysis of a higher education bubble is incomplete:
{{quote|Universities become sort of like canaries in the mine for a culture. They become the sort of standard of where a culture is going. The dynamism, the originality of these entrepreneurial experiences, the fact that a society allows people to be original, to take risks, all of it comes from a passionate love of knowledge. And universities represent all the different areas and fields within a society. And the students and faculty come from all these fields. This is a community that represents the best that a society has to offer. And there was a mention of our universities being the best in the world.<ref name=newshour>{{cite news|title=Is a College Diploma Worth the Soaring Student Debt?|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/business/jan-june11/college_05-27.html|publisher=''[[PBS NewsHour]]''|date=May 27, 2011|accessdate=November 16, 2011}}</ref>}}
=== Recommendations === Based on the available data, recommendations to address rising tuition have been advanced by experts and consumer and students' rights advocates:
* Because schools are assured of receiving their fees no matter what happens to their students, they have felt free to raise their fees to very high levels, to accept students of inadequate academic ability, and to produce too many graduates in some fields of study. Therefore, schools should be penalized when their graduates default on their student loans.<ref>{{cite web| title =Harmful Effects of Federal Student Aid: Dollars, Cents, and Nonsense| publisher =Center for College Affordability and Productivity| date =25 June 2014| url =http://centerforcollegeaffordability.org/research/studies/harmful-effects-of-federal-student-aid/| accessdate = 21 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title =Reflections on the underemployment of college graduates| publisher = Teachers College at Columbia University| date =25 June 2014| url =http://educationbythenumbers.org/content/underemployment-college-grads_1589/| accessdate = 18 January 2015}}</ref> * Tax the endowment income of universities and link the endowment tax to tuition rates.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Willie |first=Matt |title=Taxing and Tuition: A Legislative Solution to Growing Endowments and the Rising Costs of a College Degree |journal=Brigham Young University Law Review|year=2013|url=http://lawreview.byu.edu/articles/1360684178_6.willie.fin.pdf|page=1667|accessdate=19 July 2013}}</ref> * Colleges and universities should look for ways to reduce costs of instructor and administrator expenditures (e.g., cut salaries and/or reduce staff).<ref name="finaid.org">{{cite web | title=Research Report: Causes of faster-than-inflation increases in college tuition | first=Mark|last= Kantrowitz | publisher=FinAid | year=2002 | url=http://www.finaid.org/calculators/tuitionanalysis.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Watts 2011">{{cite web | title=Higher-Ed Tuition Costs: The 'Conservative' view is not on either extreme | first=GordonWayne|last=Watts | publisher=ThirstForJustice.net | year=2011 | url=http://thirstforjustice.net/Higher-Ed-Tuition-Costs.html}}</ref> * State and federal governments should increase appropriations, grants, and contracts to colleges and universities.<ref name="finaid.org"/><ref name=PIRG>{{cite web | author= | title=Affordable Higher Education: Student Debt | url=http://uspirg.org/issues/usp/affordable-higher-education | publisher=U.S. PIRG | year=2011 | accessdate=June 27, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Fight to Protect Students and Taxpayers Moves to Senate! - House Voted to Slash Pell Grants and Block Gainful Employment Rule | publisher=ProjectOnStudentDebt.org | year=2011 | url=http://projectonstudentdebt.org/update_3711.vp.html}}</ref> * Federal, state, and local governments should reduce the regulatory burden on colleges and universities.<ref name="finaid.org"/> * The federal government should enact partial or total loan forgiveness for students who have taken out student loans.<ref name="Watts 2011"/><ref>{{cite web | title=The Proposal | first=Robert | last=Applebaum | publisher=ForgiveStudentLoanDebt.com | year=2009 | url=http://forgivestudentloandebt.com/content/proposal | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728061733/http://forgivestudentloandebt.com/content/proposal | archivedate=2011-07-28 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Real Loan Forgiveness | first=|last= | publisher=ProjectOnStudentDebt.org | year=2011 | url=http://projectonstudentdebt.org/initiative_view.php?initiative_idx=8}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Take Action for Real Loan Forgiveness! | publisher=ProjectOnStudentDebt.org | year=2009 | url=http://projectonstudentdebt.org/update_61909.vp.html}}</ref> One advocate for college loan forgiveness<ref>{{cite web | title=Position Paper | first=GordonWayne|last=Watts | publisher=ThirstForJustice.net | year=2015 | url=http://thirstforjustice.net/Student-Loan-Abuse_Brief.pdf}}</ref> has argued that "Since forgiveness does not require the printing of new dollars (i.e., "too much money chasing too few goods"),<ref>{{cite web | title=Inflation: What Is Inflation? | first=Investopedia|last=Investopedia | publisher=Investopedia.com | year=2010 | url=http://www.investopedia.com/university/inflation/inflation1.asp}}</ref> it is not inflationary." Other advocates<ref>{{cite web | title=Student Loan Justice Argument | first=Garrett|last=Mockler | publisher=TheWhiteWolfHasArrived.Tumblr.com | year=2014 | url=http://thewhitewolfhasarrived.tumblr.com/post/5237203853/student-loan-justice-argument}}</ref> have argued the same thing from the opposite angle, namely that the "lack of consumer protections," particularly "removing bankruptcy protections,"<ref>{{cite web|title=What Congress Can Do To Solve the Student Loan Crisis |first=Alan |last=Collinge |publisher=NY Art World Commentary |year=2012 |url=http://newyorkartworld.com/commentary/WhatCongressCanDo-2012.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130327135831/http://newyorkartworld.com/commentary/WhatCongressCanDo-2012.html |archivedate=March 27, 2013 }}</ref> for college loans, has led to inflation. * Federal lawmakers should return standard consumer protections (truth in lending, bankruptcy proceedings, statutes of limitations, etc.) to student loans which were removed by the passage of the Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1994 (P.L. 103-394, enacted October 22, 1994), which amended the FFELP ([[Federal Family Education Loan Program]]).<ref name="Watts 2011"/><ref>{{cite web | title=Private Student Loan Bankruptcy Bill ... The 4th Attempt | first=Alan | last=Collinge | publisher=StudentLoanJustice.org | year=2011 | url=http://studentloanjustice.org/action-room.htm | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701070343/http://studentloanjustice.org/action-room.htm | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2011-07-01 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Bankruptcy Relief for Private Student Loan Borrowers Advances | publisher=ProjectOnStudentDebt.org | year=2010 | url=http://projectonstudentdebt.org/update_91610.vp.html}}</ref><ref name="Collinge 2012">{{cite web | title=Why College Prices Keep Rising | first=Alan|last=Collinge | publisher=Forbes | year=2012 | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/peterjreilly/2012/03/19/why-college-prices-keep-rising}}</ref><ref name="Watts 2016"/> * Cut lender subsidies, decrease student reliance on loans to pay for college, and otherwise reduce the 'loan limits' to limit the amount a student may borrow.<ref name="Watts 2011"/><ref name="Collinge 2012"/><ref name="Watts 2016">{{cite web | title=A Polk Perspective: Fix our bankrupt policy on student debt | first=GordonWayne|last=Watts |publisher=[[The Ledger]] | accessdate= 19 August 2016| date= 4 August 2016 | url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20160804/COLUMNISTS03/160809884/1382/edit?p=all&tc=pgall}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Affordable Higher Education: Cutting Lender Subsidies | publisher=U.S. PIRG | year=2011 | url=http://uspirg.org/issues/usp/affordable-higher-education}}</ref><ref name="Kantrowitz 2016">{{cite web | title=Why the Student Loan Crisis Is Even Worse Than People Think | first=Mark|last=Kantrowitz |publisher=[[TIME]] | accessdate= 19 August 2016| date= 11 January 2016 | url=http://time.com/money/4168510/why-student-loan-crisis-is-worse-than-people-think}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Commission: Private Loans are Not the Solution! | publisher=ProjectOnStudentDebt.org | year=2006 | url=http://ticas.org/email-update-private-loans-are-not-solution-0}}</ref> * Regulatory or legislative action to lower or freeze the tuition, such as [[Canada]]'s [[tuition freeze]] model, should be enacted by federal lawmakers:<ref>{{cite web | title=Commission Calls for "Reduced Debt Burden" -- Time for Education Department to Act | publisher=ProjectOnStudentDebt.org | year=2006 | url=http://projectonstudentdebt.org/update_81806.vp.html}}</ref> Potential downsides to tuition-freezing guarantees are evident, being offered by only a few dozen colleges. Under the guarantees, the student's tuition does not change for the extent of their education. Each year's freshmen pay a higher rate, which is then guaranteed through their years in college.<ref name="LAT2012">{{cite web | title=Freezing tuition: It's not such a hot idea. | publisher= Los Angeles Times | year=2012 | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/jul/06/opinion/la-ed-tuition-freeze-20120706}}</ref> About 1 in 3 college students transfers to another school at some point. If tuition freezes become the default model for colleges, students would feel less able to change schools because they would be entering at a new, probably higher tuition.<ref name="LAT2012" /> ** More research should be done: Recognised financial expert, Mark Kantrowitz, issued the following recommendations:<ref name="finaid.org"/> :* "The National Center for Education Statistics should increase the frequency of the National Postsecondary Student Aid Study to annual, from triennial, in order to permit more timely tracking of the factors affecting tuition rate increases. Likewise, NCES (National Center for Education Statistics) should take steps to improve the efficiency of the data collection and publication for the Digest of Education Statistics, so that all tables will include more recent data. The most recent data listed in some tables is five years old." :* "The US Department of Education should study the relationship between increases in average EFC (Expected Family Contribution) figures and average tuition rates. In addition, it would be worthwhile to examine how historical average EFC figures have changed relative to family income when measured on a current and constant dollar basis for each income quartile." * Other popular ways to address the rising tuition problems faced by students include completing your general education requirements at a community college, which is much cheaper than initially going to a university, obtaining scholarships and other financial aid, as well as looking for ways to pay in-state tuition.<ref name=Cutting>{{cite web | last=Kantrowitz | first=Mark | title=Cutting College Costs|publisher=FinAid|year=2013|url=http://www.finaid.org/questions/cuttingcollegecosts.phtml|accessdate= 24 July 2013}}</ref> * Lastly, in order to cope with the rising cost of tuition, many students have started working part-time.<ref name="Cutting"/><ref>{{cite web | title=How to Cope with Rising Tuition Costs|publisher=Global Campus For Students|year=2011|url=http://www.gcstudent.org/how-to-cope-with-rising-tuition-costs|accessdate= 22 July 2013}}</ref> When it comes to getting a job after college, to further cope with the rising costs of tuition, some experts have suggested that the best move might be to get a job while in college.<ref>{{cite web|last=Watson|first=Bruce|title=How to Go to College Without Going Broke (and Yes, You Still Should)|url=http://www.dailyfinance.com/2011/11/03/how-to-go-to-college-without-going-broke-and-yes-you-still-sho|publisher=Daily Finance|date=3 November 2011| accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> To facilitate these recommendations, some colleges help students in job searches and job placement after graduation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Top 10 Job Placement Colleges: INFORMATION AND TIPS ON INTERNSHIPS AND PAID INTERNSHIP|publisher=CollegeTips.com| year=2011|url=http://www.collegetips.com/college-money/college-job-placement.php|accessdate= 22 July 2013}}</ref>

'''Independent study''' is a form of [[education]] offered by many high schools, colleges, and other educational institutions.<ref name="HendersonNathenson1984" /> It is sometimes referred to as ''directed study'', and is an educational activity undertaken by an individual with little to no supervision.<ref name="Moore2009" /> Typically a student and professor or teacher agree upon a topic for the student to research with guidance from the instructor for an agreed upon amount of credits.<ref name="Winebrenner2012" /> Independent studies provide a way for well-motivated students to pursue a topic of interest that does not necessarily fit into a traditional academic curriculum.<ref>{{cite web|title=Independent Study|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/ah/programs/graduate/independent-study.html|accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref> They are a way for students to learn specialized material or gain research experience.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hacker|title=Using a Blog in an Independent Study|url=http://chronicle.com/blogs/profhacker/using-a-blog-in-an-independent-study/35486|publisher=Chronicles of Higher Learning|accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref>
Independent studies provide students opportunities to explore their interests deeper and make important decisions about how and where they will direct their talents in the future.<ref name=Fetterman1988 /> Another way to understand independent study is to understand [[Distance education|learning from a distance]]. Learning from a distance is a theory in which the student is at a physical or a mental distance from his or her teacher. The student and the teacher are connected by something such as a worksheet, an essay, or through a website on the internet.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Moore|first1=Michael Grahame|title=Toward a theory of independent learning and teaching.|journal=The Journal of Higher Education|date=1973|pages=661–679}}</ref>
==Independent study programs==
For elementary and junior high, independent study is sometimes a Gifted and Talented Education (GATE) program, where the student must research the topic and formulate and answer questions.<ref name="Fetterman1988" /> At the end, they develop and present a product, although not all GATE systems participate in this.<ref name="knight2006" />
Many charter schools in the US provide independent study and [[homeschooling]] in a variety of formats: online, in-person or a hybrid of online/in-person interaction.<ref name="English1999" /><ref name="Curry2013" /> These independent study programs are particularly helpful for those who find a traditional classroom setting to be unsatisfactory. For example, independent study is ideal for those who have children, health issues, intense work schedules, or gifted academic ability.<ref>{{cite web|title=Independent Study|url=http://www.cde.ca.gov/sp/eo/is/|publisher=California Department of Education|accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref> Often students with high scholastic standing are encouraged to take independent studies to try to learn without attendance in a class.<ref>{{cite book|last=Littleton|first=A.C.|author-link=Ananias Charles Littleton |title=The Accounting Exchange|date=June 1933|pages=160|jstor=238320}}</ref> Independent study is also useful for self-directed learning activities that allow the student to be self-reliant.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Empey|first=Donald W.|title=Independent Study|journal=The Clearing House|year=1968|page=229}}</ref>
A program titled "The Research Experiences for Undergraduates" (REU) has been founded by the National Science Foundation which provides funding for undergraduates to engage in different areas of research outside of the classroom. Groups are formed of graduates, undergraduates, and faculty to work on a specific research project.<ref name=Lang>{{cite web|last=Lang|first=James|title=Doing Research with Undergraduates|url=http://chronicle.com/article/Doing-Research-With/128613/|publisher=The Chronicle of Higher Education|accessdate= 19 February 2014}}</ref>
==Personality types==
Studies have shown that personality can influence whether a person enjoys an independent study project, rather than lectures. People that believe the teacher should be authoritarian did not perform well in independent studies. However, there is evidence to suggest that personality should not solely dictate who is allowed to receive independent study.<ref name=Personality>{{cite journal|last=Koenig|first=Kathryn|author2=W.J. McKeachie|title=Personality and Independent Study|journal=Journal of Educational Psychology|date=June 1959|volume=50|issue=3|doi=10.1037/h0041286 }}<!--|accessdate=2014-03-19--></ref>
Though not afforded the same attention as individual personality on behalf of the potential student, some interest should be given to the teachers and or professor's ability to relate to the distance learner. Breaking the mold of in-class instruction versus the distance learner can be a difficult task to undertake by the instructor. They are not the same environment and changes and or accommodations should be made while keeping integrity of the overall class.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}

[[File:AlfredTarski1968.jpeg|thumb|none|Alfred Tarski]] [[File:Stanisław Leśniewski.jpg|thumb|none|Stanisław Leśniewski]] [[File:Maria Ossowska.jpg|thumb|none|Maria Ossowska]]
'''Institute of Philosophy''' of the [[University of Warsaw]] (Polish ''Instytut filozofii Uniwersytetu Warszawskiego'') is a research institution located in Warsaw, part of the Faculty of Philosophy and Sociology of the University of Warsaw. It is renowned mainly for its contribution to the development of modern [[logic]] and [[analytic philosophy]] ([[Lwów–Warsaw school of logic|Lvov-Warsaw School]] - [[Alfred Tarski]], [[Jan Łukasiewicz]], [[Kazimierz Ajdukiewicz]], [[Tadeusz Kotarbiński]], [[Stanisław Leśniewski]]) and to [[history of ideas]] ([[Warsaw School of the History of Ideas]] - [[Władysław Tatarkiewicz]], [[Stanisław Ossowski]], [[Maria Ossowska]], [[Leszek Kołakowski]], [[Adam Schaff]]). Provides master's degree studies, doctor's degree studies and postgraduate studies in philosophy both in Polish and in English. == The 18th and 19th century == The main centre of the medieval and early modern [[History of philosophy in Poland|Polish philosophy]] was [[Kraków]] - history of philosophy in Warsaw begins in the 18th century. In the pre-partition Varsovian institutions, the [[Collegium Nobilium (Warsaw)|Collegium Nobilium]] and the [[Corps of Cadets (Warsaw)|Szkoła Rycerska]] to the lecturers of philosophy belonged [[Antoni Wiśniewski]] and [[Marcin Nikuta]]. In the 19th century, after the foundation of the University of Warsaw in 1815, due to [[russification]] of the schools Polish philosophy, both idealist and positivist, developed mainly outside universities. Among main Polish philosophers connected with the 19th century University of Warsaw were [[Adam Zabellewicz]] and [[Henryk Struve]]. == Interwar period == After 1918, when Poland regained independence, University of Warsaw was reorganized. Chairs of philosophy were held by [[Jan Łukasiewicz]], [[Władysław Tatarkiewicz]], [[Tadeusz Kotarbiński]], [[Stanisław Leśniewski]], [[Kazimierz Ajdukiewicz]] and [[Stanisław Schayer]]. Initially, philosophical education were organized in the Faculty of Historical-Philosophical Studies (1915–16), soon transformed into the Faculty of Philosophical Studies (1916–27), and then into the Faculty of the Humanities (Tatarkiewicz, Kotarbiński and Schayer) and the Faculty of Mathematical Studies and Physics (Łukasiewicz, Leśniewski and Ajdukiewicz). Other important philosophers teaching in Warsaw were [[Alfred Tarski]], [[Henryk Elzenberg]], [[Maria Ossowska]] and [[Stanisław Ossowski]]. Worldwide renown in [[logic]] and [[analytic philosophy]] was enjoyed by the Warsaw School of Logic, part of the philosophical movement of [[Lwów–Warsaw school of logic|Lvov-Warsaw School]]. During the German occupation of Warsaw secret courses of philosophy were conducted by Łukasiewcz, Tatarkiewicz, Kotarbiński and others. == History after 1945 == After 1945, during the stalinist era, due to political predominance of marxist philosophy in Poland some professors were partially prohibited from pursuing didactic activity. After the [[Polish October]] (1956) a separate Faculty of Philosophical Studies (1954–65) emerged from the Faculty of Arts and many leading philosophers were allowed to teach. It was subsequently transformed into the Faculty of Philosophical-Sociological Studies (1965–68). In the 50. and 60. [[Warsaw School of the History of Ideas]] emerged. To this informal group of non-analytical philosophers belonged mainly former marxists (called "revisionist"), inspired to some extent by the ideas of Tatarkiewicz and Ossowskis. After the [[1968 Polish political crisis|Polish March]] (1968), when many "revisionist" Polish philosophers and sociologists (for example [[Leszek Kołakowski]], [[Zygmunt Bauman]], [[Adam Schaff]]) participated in the events, philosophy at Warsaw University was subjected to a thorough reorganization. Chairs were renamed to departments and the Faculty of Philosophical Studies were forcibly joined with the Faculty of Sociology, within which the Institute of Philosophy was established. In the post-war period the tradition of Lvov-Warsaw School was also continued. To the most important philosophers and logicians of the post-war period connected with the University of Warsaw belong [[Kazimierz Ajdukiewicz]], [[Zdzisław Augustynek]], [[Bronisław Baczko]], [[Marek Fritzhand]], [[Henryk Jankowski]], [[Andrzej Kasia]], [[Leszek Kołakowski]], [[Władysław Krajewski]], [[Tadeusz Kroński]], [[Jan Legowicz]], [[Stefan Morawski]], [[Elżbieta Pietruska-Madej]], [[Marian Przełęcki]], [[Adam Schaff]], [[Marek Siemek]], [[Adam Sikora]], [[Roman Suszko]], [[Klemens Szaniawski]] and [[Bogusław Wolniewicz]]. == Current structure == *Analytic Philosophy Department **prof. '''The International University of the Caribbean (IUC)''' was founded by the United Church in Jamaica and the Cayman Islands in November 2005. It consists of two educational entities: College for Leadership and Theological Development (CLTD) [formerly the Institute for Theological and Leadership Development] and the Mel Nathan College.
== Location-based study == The university has regional campuses, community campuses and delivery centres to cover the majority of Jamaica and the Cayman Islands.
== Accreditation == The University Council of Jamaica (UCJ) is the accrediting body for tertiary programmes in Jamaica.
There are several accredited programmes offered through College for Leadership and Theological Development (CTLD) [formerly Institute for Theological and Leadership Development] and Mel Nathan College (MNC)
* Diploma in Theology * Bachelor of Arts in Theology * Bachelor of Arts in General Studies * Bachelor of Arts in Guidance and Counselling (degree completion) * Bachelor of Arts in Guidance and Counselling (4-year degree) * Bachelor of Education (Primary) * Bachelor of Arts in Psychology * Master of Arts in Pastoral Psychology and Counselling (MAPPC)
Accredited MNC programmes:
* Bachelor of Arts in Community Development * Bachelor of Science in Business Administration with specialization in Programme and Project Management * Bachelor of Science in Business Administration
Accreditation is currently being sought for all other programmes through the UCJ.
The normal procedure is for programmes to be delivered in keeping with UCJ guidelines and then submitted for accreditation after the graduation of the first cohort.
== Scholarships == The International University of the Caribbean currently offers two (2) exciting scholarship opportunities: Tertiary Track Scholarship and First Steps Scholarship.
The Tertiary Track Scholarship is awarded to candidates based on their defined financial need, history of involvement in community work and their display of potential to be effective role models in their respective communities. Applicants are interviewed by a panel of IUC representatives prior to approval.
The First Steps Scholarship is a discount in the amount of $70,000.00 on your tuition fee for the first year of your selected programme. The programmes offered with this scholarship may vary each academic year.
The programmes on offer for 2011/2012 academic year are:
1. Bachelor of Arts in General Studies 2. Bachelor of Science in Business Administration 3. Bachelor of Arts in Community Development 4. Bachelor of Science in Human Resource Management 5. Bachelor of Arts in Psychology 6. Bachelor of Arts in Guidance and Counselling
